Topic.Title: I Just Took A Very Large Long Position Here On Friday!

Message.Msg: It's usually a good idea to buy into a new position in at least 2 to 4 "chunks" over a month or more period to insure you get it at a reasonable average representative price within that intraquarter period. A stock tends to be more heavily traded during the weeks immediately following the earnings cycle, and sometimes fading interest combined with profit taking allows choice between earnings deals for the patient investor. And, by the book, there is NOTHING wrong with averaging a position UP, nor, if you were going to take the entire position for a long term ride to begin with, averaging down, provided there is real value there for your money. Value that I agree this stock has. Good luck though, not that you'll need it on this one, just alittle time.

Topic.Title: John McCain: Chuck Hagel Will Likely Be Confirmed

Message.Msg: Republican field is large enough to pick someone who is not upset with jewish lobby in US government. Democrat field is wide open too, there are many who are not anti-Semites. We are better off with Panetta, at least he understands that sequestration is bad for the military. Now, how many Supreme Court nominees were filibustered by Democrats in the Senate under Bush? Do we need functional judicial branch too? Well, at least W showed some flexibility by making another nomination. For Obama it is all about making GOP look bad. Country in front of ideology? We wouldn't add nearly as much to national debt if this president would really care about the country. He doesn't.

We all know that was a spike due to oil disruption threrats, so stop with the obfuscation. Now, your boy has resided over the most consistent high gas prices ever. Better buy some out of the money Decmember USO Calls, just in case Isreal has to do what the community organizer won't do...stop Iran from producing a nuclear bomb!

Message.Title: Plunge protection team
Message.Msg: Everytime the markets tries to sell off the market rallies into the close, reminds me of the mid 2000 when the PPT did the same maneuver...this time I think this is BBPP (Ben Bernanke plunge protection). His whole being is ridding on keeping the S&P heading north in spite of real sustained economic growth. Now he is even killing Bond returns which will force folks that can least afford it back into equities...retired and and fixed income folks. These bankers never learn, but then again they will be bailed out while the "little people" will lose what these crooks on WS didn't take during the last colapse..se la ve!

Message.Title: Quick look at the technicals ..
Message.Msg: Be careful here .. ETFC closed under the 5 ema for the first time in over 20 days ( Daily View ).. The rsi is decreasing and your about to see a macd crossover to the downside . Also , the nasdaq looks as if it has topped .. If your long ETFC , you may want to consider taking some profits . Good luck !!
CNBC's special "Smart Guys in the Room"... Read Matt Taibbis' "The Great American Bubble Machine"... Then you will Know why thing are the way they are.

Elections have consequenses and the "little people" will get what they voted for. Only thing to do here is make provision the best way you can and hopefully come out the other side intacted after it all comes crashing down.....and it will, eventually.

Topic.Title: I thought this was a ETFC board, cut the freakin political #$%$ and post etfc info only!

Message.Msg: Then why wait to dump it. I invested in RSH hoping the CEO could turn it around, but when he left and they hired a faithless pogue who lied about their dividend intentions I dropped it like a rock instead of "waiting to break even". I mean, what's the point, as if you think a company is doomed to failure then likely others are reaching the same conclusion and already beginning to divest their interest. Waiting only leaves you a bagholder, so instead you should be selling this recent pop and then, if you want to try to recover some losses, buy back in on a hard drop and ride the bouncing cat to additional profits, or, even a better idea, just eat the loss and move on to a stock with a more stable future that's also ready for a bounce. I ditched the Shack and lost a TON of money, so much that it wiped out all my other gains for the year and that again in realized losses. But, if I'd stayed in, I would have been sitting on dead money for months and wouldn't have made the subsequent realized and unrealized gains that made up almost all that loss in the last few months. Never hold onto what you think is a loser just to "get even" as if you're right about it being a loser all you'll do is "get screwed".
